choices.text: Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs
Two doses 12 hrs apart
Three doses 12 hrs apart
None of the above

questions.text: For emergency contraception, a single tab of 0.75 mg of LNG was taken, it should be followed by which of the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs

 

Explanation:

 

  • In this case, the 2nd dose of LNG 0.75 mg (levonorgestrel) is taken after 12 hours.
  • One tablet of LNG 0.75mg should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and another 12 hours later.
  • Alternately, two tablets (of 0.75mg) or a single 1.5mg tablet can be taken as a single dose.
  • The tablets can be offered up to 72h of an act of unprotected intercourse, but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval.

 

Other emergency contraceptives available:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency contraception using levonorgestrel requires a follow-up dose of 0.75 mg taken 12 hours after the initial dose to ensure efficacy.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Genital Tuberculosis

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perineal area, difficulty in walking and sitting. She has a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, a tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bartholin abscess

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and image points to the diagnosis of Bartholin's abscess.

 

Bartholin Cyst and Abscess

 

Bartholin gland is a mucus-secreting gland, which plays a role in vaginal lubrication. They are a pair of 0.5 cm glands located in the lower right and left portions at the 4 o’clock and 8 o’clock positions of the vaginal introitus. They are generally nonpalpable when not obstructed.

 

Pathophysiology: Bartholin glands can form a cyst and an abscess in women of reproductive age and may cause dyspareunia, urinary irritation, and vague pelvic pain.

 

C/F:

 

  • The physical exam will often reveal asymmetry with a protrusion of one side (left or right) of the inferior aspect of the vulva.
  • Bartholin gland abscesses, unlike Bartholin cysts, are very painful.
  • While both are primarily unilateral, Bartholin abscesses are often tender to palpation, erythematous, indurated, and may have an area of fluctuance and/or purulent drainage.
  • Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Bartholin cysts do not require further treatment.
  • Bartholin abscesses may be treated with incision and drainage with Word catheter placement due to ease and effectiveness of treatment.
  • Marsupialization is the procedure of choice.
  • Women with recurrent cysts or those who are post-menopausal (risk of malignancy) should have the cyst completely excised.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chlamydial infection: Chlamydial infection patient usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, or cervicitis.

 

Option C. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis involves the upper genital tract, leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility, and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Genital herpes: Genital herpes usually presents as painful ulcers or vesicles in the genital area, rather than a tender, erythematous swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Bartholin abscess presents with significant pain, redness, and swelling in the labia, often making walking and sitting difficult.

questions.text: A patient presents at 36 weeks with chronic HTN and 3+ proteinuria. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and she complains of headache and blurring of vision. What is the best management option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Labetalol + MgSO4 + Expedite delivery

 

This patient is presenting with chronic hypertension that has progressed to superimposed preeclampsia, indicated by the development of 3+ proteinuria, a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg, and symptoms such as headache and blurring of vision. These symptoms and her elevated blood pressure suggest severe preeclampsia.

 

  • Severe Preeclampsia: A systolic blood pressure greater than 160 mmHg or a diastolic blood pressure greater than 110 mmHg, along with symptoms like headache and visual disturbances, are indicators of severe preeclampsia. In this case, the patient’s condition requires urgent management to prevent the development of eclampsia, a condition that can lead to seizures and other severe complications.
  • Management: The correct management for severe preeclampsia at 36 weeks gestation includes the administration of Labetalol to lower the blood pressure, Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) to prevent seizures, and expedited delivery to resolve the preeclampsia. After 34 weeks of gestation, delivery is recommended for severe preeclampsia because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labetalol + MgSO4 + Wait till 37 weeks: As this is severe preeclampsia, there is a very high risk waiting till 37 weeks. Immediate delivery is indicated after 34 weeks

 

Option C. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + wait till 37 weeks: There is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks and also there is no indication to wait till 37 weeks as this is severe preeclampsia

 

Option D. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + Expedite delivery: Although delivery needs to be expedited, there is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe preeclampsia after 34 weeks, immediate delivery, blood pressure control with labetalol, and seizure prophylaxis with magnesium sulfate are essential for optimal maternal and fetal outcomes.

choices.text: Superficial transverse perineal

questions.text: The deepest part of perineal body injury, which causes cystocele, enterocoele and urethral descent is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pubococcygeus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle.
  • Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent.
  • The levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction.
  • Weakening of this muscle decreases support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bulbospongiosus, Option C. ischiocavernosus and Option D. superficial transverse perineal are all superficial muscles and their damage does not result in uterovaginal descent

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Supports of the vagal have been described by Delancey as shown below and defects in these lead to different levels of uterovaginal prolapse
    • Defect in Level 1 support: Vaginal apical prolapse and uterine prolapse
    • Defect in level 2 support: Cystocele and Rectocele
    • Defect in level 3 support: urethrocele and deficient perineal body

 

 

Ref: Page no 544, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 22y type 1 DM is in the post operative ward following a cesarean done for failed induction (for preeclampsia with severe features). She complains of drowsiness and altered sensorium. She is on maintenance MgSO4 infusion and on IV infusion of insulin. On examination, her PR is 70/ min. BP is 140/ 98 mmHg. RR is 10/min. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral normal air entry. Abdominal examination reveals a firm uterus with normal tenderness. Pfannenstiel scar is intact and there is no significant vaginal bleeding. B/l patellar reflexes are absent. A urine dipstick for protein and sugar is negative and a capillary glucose sample is 270 mg%. The suspected diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnesium sulphate toxicity

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: This is unlikely as urine for sugars is absent.

 

Option C. Postpartum eclampsia: This is unlikely as there is no history of seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: There is no evidence of cardiac failure and hence this is also unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia, it is critical to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity, which include loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest. The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate.

 

Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: What dose of misoprostol is administered orally to manage post-partum hemorrhage? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 600 micrograms

 

Explanation:

 

The recommended oral dose of misoprostol for the emergent management of postpartum hemorrhage is 600 micrograms. Studies have shown that administering 600 micrograms of misoprostol at the time of delivery significantly reduces the incidence of hemorrhage and severe hemorrhage. Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue, effective in preventing and treating uterine atony and postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 400 micrograms - This dose is less effective in controlling postpartum hemorrhage compared to 600 micrograms.

 

Option C. 800 micrograms - Although higher doses may be used, 600 micrograms is the standard recommended dose for oral administration.

 

Option D. 1000 micrograms - This dose is not commonly recommended for oral administration in managing postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard oral dose of misoprostol for controlling postpartum hemorrhage is 600 micrograms

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer
Increases risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

questions.text: HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18,31,33,45,52,58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/news/item/20-12-2022-WHO-updates-recommendations-on-HPV-vaccination-schedule

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

choices.text: Pelvic organ prolapse with rectocele
Pelvic organ prolapse with cystocele

questions.text: A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman visits the gynecology clinic with complaints of a sensation of heaviness and a visible bulge protruding from her vaginal opening, which she first noticed several years ago but has progressively worsened. She describes intermittent urinary incontinence, difficulty emptying her bladder, and recent constipation, which she attributes to the pressure she feels in her lower abdomen. She denies any recent trauma or significant weight gain but mentions a history of multiple vaginal deliveries. The patient has no history of pelvic surgery. On pelvic examination, a mass is visible protruding beyond the vaginal introitus, and the cervix is noted to be at or beyond the level of the vaginal opening. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Uterocervical prolapse

 

Explanation:


Uterocervical prolapse occurs when the uterus and cervix descend into the vaginal canal due to weakened pelvic floor muscles and ligaments, often caused by factors such as multiple vaginal deliveries, advancing age, and postmenopausal hypoestrogenism. This condition typically presents with symptoms of pelvic pressure, a visible protruding mass at the vaginal introitus, urinary incontinence, and bowel dysfunction, as observed in this patient.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Pelvic organ prolapse with rectocele: Rectocele refers to the herniation of the rectum into the posterior vaginal wall, commonly presenting as a posterior bulge that causes symptoms of constipation and difficulty with bowel movements. Unlike uterocervical prolapse, it does not involve the descent of the cervix or uterus.

 

Option C. Pelvic organ prolapse with cystocele: Cystocele involves the protrusion of the bladder into the anterior vaginal wall, often presenting with urinary symptoms such as urgency, frequency, and stress incontinence. The physical examination would reveal a bulge from the anterior vaginal wall rather than the centrally positioned mass seen with uterocervical prolapse.

 

Option D. Vaginal vault prolapse: Vaginal vault prolapse occurs in patients who have undergone a hysterectomy, leading to the descent of the vaginal apex. It typically presents with pelvic pressure and a vaginal bulge but lacks the specific involvement of the cervix and uterus seen in uterocervical prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:


Uterocervical prolapse is a condition characterized by the descent of the uterus and cervix into the vaginal canal, often seen in postmenopausal women with a history of multiple vaginal deliveries. It presents with pelvic pressure, visible protrusion from the vaginal introitus, and associated urinary and bowel symptoms, necessitating appropriate clinical evaluation and management.

choices.text: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the treatment of PCOD except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulipristal

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of PCOD.
    • It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator.
    • It is used as an emergency contraceptive and in medical management of fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene: Clomiphene is an anti-estrogen used in ovulation induction in women with PCOS (1st line agent) and infertility

 

  • Gonadotropins can also be used in PCOS with infertility in those who have clomiphene resistance (2nd line therapy)

 

Option B. Letrozole: But nowadays Letrozole (aromatase inhibitor) is the drug for ovulation induction in PCOS with infertility.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling: It is recommended as second-line therapy in PCOS

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator primarily used for emergency contraception and managing uterine fibroids.

 

Ref: Page 244, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Endometrial hyperplasia

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenomyosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. The uterus is generally uniformly enlarged up to 12-14 weeks size and can be tender on examination.
  • Investigation of choice: Ultrasound
  • On ultrasound, the following can be seen in adenomyosis:

 

 

  • Management of adenomyosis
    • Medical management: For symptomatic relief
    • Total Hysterectomy (Definitive treatment - Treatment of choice if family is complete)

 

Other options

 

Option A. Endometriosis: This presents as 5Ds (Dysmenorrhoea, Dyspareunia, Dyschezia, Dysfertility and Dull-aching abdominal pain). Diagnostic modality of choice is laparoscopy. Myometrial cysts are not seen. Endometriotic (chocolate) cysts in the ovary may be seen.

 

Option C. Leiomyoma: Fibroids or leiomyomas usually present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. If very large, they will present with abdominal mass and pelvic pressure. On ultrasound, depending on the location, well circumscribed rounded lesions are seen.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: This will present as menorrhagia. On ultrasound the endometrium will be thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenomyosis is characterized by a uniformly enlarged uterus with myometrial cysts, diagnosed primarily via ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 196, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia
Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia
Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia: Endothelial cell dysfunction is another etiology. Injured or activated endothelial cells may produce less nitric oxide and may secrete substances that promote coagulation and vasopressor sensitivity.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia: Vasospasm has long been associated with preeclampsia. Systemic endothelial activation causes vasospasm, which elevates resistance to produce hypertension. With diminished blood flow because of maldistribution from vasospasm and interstitial leakage, ischemia of the surrounding tissues can cause necrosis, hemorrhage, and other end-organ disturbances.

 

Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:

 

Angiogenic Factors:

 

  • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased
    • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1)
    • Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • Factors that are decreased are
    • PlGF
    • PAPP-A
    • VEGF

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preeclampsia, the prostacyclin: thromboxane ratio is decreased due to increased thromboxane A2 and decreased prostacyclin (PGI2).

 

Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora for a period of 6 months, measuring 2 cm x 3 cm. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. How do you manage this case? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has a midline lesion on the labia majora, which indicates that the lesion is close to or crossing the midline. In cases of midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline, bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is necessary along with radical vulvectomy. This approach ensures that all potential pathways of lymphatic spread are adequately addressed.

 

New (2021) FIGO staging for carcinoma of the vulva:

 

  • Tumors 2 cm or less in size with 1 mm or less invasion: Treated by wide local excision.
  • Tumors more than 2 cm with more than 1 mm depth of invasion: Treated by modified radical vulvectomy with groin lymph node dissection.
  • LN dissection through separate incision: Lymph node dissection should be inguino-femoral.
  • Bilateral lymph node dissection: Performed for midline lesions and those within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Unilateral dissection: If the lesion is unilateral and ipsilateral nodes are negative, bilateral dissection is not necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection: This would be appropriate for unilateral lesions with no evidence of contralateral spread, but not for midline lesions.

 

Option C. Simple vulvectomy: Simple vulvectomy is not sufficient for managing invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a lesion size of 2 cm x 3 cm and potential for deeper invasion.

 

Option D. Chemoradiation with resection: Chemoradiation followed by resection is typically reserved for advanced or inoperable cases, or where there is a need to downstage the tumor before surgery. This case can be managed surgically given the size and lack of palpable lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline in squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva, radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is the appropriate management.

 

Ref: FIGO staging of CA vulva, Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15th edition pg 1436, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 484-485.

questions.text: All of the following can be used in first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate:
    • This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • Medical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Mifepristone + misoprostol: A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Manual vacuum aspiration: This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester.
    • Dilatation and curettage: Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone + misoprostol: Mifepristone + misoprostol is a commonly used combination for medical termination in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration: Manual vacuum aspiration is a standard procedure for first-trimester abortion.

 

Option C. Dilatation and evacuation: Dilatation and evacuation is another method used in the first trimester to terminate a pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg364,369, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg203

questions.text: The maximum capacity of a Bakri balloon used in postpartum hemorrhage? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 500 mL

 

Explanation:

 

The Bakri balloon is designed to manage postpartum hemorrhage by tamponading the uterine cavity to stop bleeding. Its maximum capacity is 500 mL. During the procedure, the balloon is initially inflated with at least 150 mL of fluid and then gradually increased to a total volume of 300 to 500 mL to effectively control hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 200 mL - This is below the maximum capacity and may not be sufficient to control severe hemorrhage.

 

Option B. 300 mL - Although part of the inflation process, it is not the maximum capacity.

d. 1000 mL - This exceeds the designed capacity of the Bakri balloon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bakri balloon can hold up to 500 mL of fluid to effectively manage postpartum hemorrhage

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

 

Explanation:

 

 Hysteroscopy and septoplasty:

 

  • Uterine septum is a Mullerian anomaly where the uterine cavity is completely or partially separated by a septum. This can lead to infertility, recurrent abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, malpresentations, and retained placenta.
  • The diagnosis of a uterine septum can be confirmed through hysterosalpingography (HSG), 3D ultrasound, MRI, or hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty) is the appropriate management as it involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum, which improves reproductive outcomes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the removal of the uterus, is not an appropriate management for a uterine septum in a woman desiring fertility. This would completely eliminate her ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy and metroplasty: While laparoscopy can be used to visualize the external uterine anatomy, metroplasty (surgical correction of the uterus) is better performed via hysteroscopy for a uterine septum. Laparoscopy is more invasive and not the first-line approach for this condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy and metroplasty: Laparotomy is an open surgical procedure that involves a larger incision in the abdomen. This approach is unnecessarily invasive for the correction of a uterine septum, which can be effectively managed with a less invasive hysteroscopic approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a uterine septum, especially in a woman seeking fertility, is hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty), which involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum and improve reproductive outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's favorability for induction, and a score of 5 in this context would be based on specific factors.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: The following instrument is used for……:  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAP smear

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shown is that of Ayre's spatula which is used for preparing PAP smear.
  • It is used to scrape the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix while preparing a Pap smear.
  • A cytobrush is used to take endocervical samples
  • The smear is fixed with 95% ethanol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIA: This is Visual Inspection under Acetic Acid. This is done by applying acetic acid on the cervix. Any acetowhite area is suspicious for dysplasia. It is done in low resource settings.

 

Option B. VILI: Visual inspection under Lugol Iodine: This is done by applying Lugol’s iodine on the cervix. A dysplastic area will not take up iodine. It is also done in low resource settings.

 

 

Option D. Colposcopy: This is a magnified view of the cervix. It is done in patients with abnormal pap smear/ HPV +Ve/ VIA +ve or VILI +ve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ayre's spatula is used for preparing a Pap smear by scraping cells from the cervix for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Page no 325, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

The given set of instruments are commonly used for taking a Pap smear. The instruments include:

 

  • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix.
  • Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample.
  • Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample.
  • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively.
  • Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure involves using a hysteroscope to visualize the inside of the uterine cavity, and the instruments shown are not used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Biopsy: While some of these instruments might be used in a cervical biopsy, the specific combination shown is typically for a Pap smear.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure involves dilating the cervix and scraping the endometrial lining, which requires different instruments than those shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The set of instruments shown, including Cusco's speculum, Koplin's jar, slides, Ayer's spatula, endocervical brush, and fixative, are used for performing a Pap smear to collect and preserve cervical cell samples for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

choices.text: 6 to 10 weeks
8 to 12 weeks
13 to 20 weeks
20 to 28 weeks

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 13 to 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) is a double-stranded DNA virus that is primarily acquired in childhood and causes chickenpox. The virus is transmitted through direct contact with an infected individual. Nonimmune pregnant women who come into close contact with a patient with chickenpox are at risk of contracting the infection.

 

If a pregnant woman contracts chickenpox, particularly early in pregnancy, there is a risk of congenital varicella syndrome in the fetus. The highest risk period for the development of congenital varicella syndrome is between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Congenital varicella syndrome includes the following features:

 

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

 

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active VZV infection just before or during delivery (less than 5 days before and up to 2 days after delivery), there is a significant risk of disseminated disease and CNS involvement in the neonate, with a mortality rate of approximately 30%. In such cases, administration of VZIG (Varicella-Zoster Immune Globulin) is recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest risk period for the development of congenital varicella syndrome in a fetus is when the mother is infected with Varicella Zoster Virus between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 3085

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruptio placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Abruptio placentae, also known as placental abruption, commonly occurs in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. It is characterized by the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and often fetal distress or fetal death. The uterus may be tonically contracted in such cases.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypertensive Disorders: Abruptio placentae is frequently associated with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.
  • Clinical Presentation: Painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements are hallmark signs.
  • Uterine Contraction: The uterus may feel firm and tender, indicating a tonic contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa involves painless vaginal bleeding due to the placenta covering the cervix. It generally does not cause decreased fetal movements unless there is severe bleeding leading to maternal and fetal compromise.

 

Option C. Hydramnios: Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) involves excessive amniotic fluid and does not typically present with bleeding.

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor typically does not present with bleeding and is characterized by regular uterine contractions leading to cervical changes before 37 weeks of gestation. Prematurity in preterm labor is iatrogenic if induced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abruptio placenta should be suspected in a hypertensive pregnant woman presenting with painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements, as it is commonly associated with hypertensive disorders and presents with these clinical features.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1944

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

 

Explanation:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis: This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry: This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.

 

Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the antigen present in the recombinant HPV vaccine?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L1

 

Explanation:

 

The recombinant HPV vaccine primarily includes the L1 protein, which self-assembles into virus-like particles, providing the basis for immune recognition without causing the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E1 + E2: E1 and E2 are early viral proteins, not included in vaccines due to their role in viral replication.

 

Option B. E6 + E7: E6 and E7 are proteins involved in oncogenesis, not appropriate for vaccine development.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is also a capsid protein but not the primary antigen used in current HPV vaccines.

 

Educational objective:

 

The L1 protein of HPV forms the basis of the recombinant HPV vaccine, effectively stimulating an immune response by mimicking the virus structure.

choices.text: 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts
13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts

questions.text: Which of the following patients would be classified as having primary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts

 

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as:
    • No menstruation by age 13 in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No menstruation by age 15 in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • In this context:
    • Option A: An 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts would not be classified as having primary amenorrhea since she is not yet 13.
    • Option B: A 14-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts meets the criteria for primary amenorrhea because she is older than 13 and has no secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 1 breasts).
    • Option C: A 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.
    • Option D: A 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts is developing normally and does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 11-year-old girl with Tanner stage 1 breasts: The girl is too young to be classified as having primary amenorrhea.

 

Option C. 13-year-old girl with Tanner stage 5 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Option D. 12-year-old with Tanner stage 4 breasts: The girl has developed secondary sexual characteristics and is within the normal age range for the onset of menstruation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by age 13 without secondary sexual characteristics or by age 15 with secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Ref: ACOG Committee opinion menstruation in girls and adolescents (2015), Speroff’s gynecologic endocrinology 7th edition pg401, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 450

questions.text: Which of the following anti rheumatoid drug increases extracellular adenosine? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

Methotrexate works primarily by inhibiting AICAR transformylase and thymidylate synthetase.

 

AICAR accumulates intracellularly and competes with AMP deaminase, resulting in AMP accumulation. AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is acts as the powerful anti-inflammatory agent. As a result, neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes' inflammatory functions are suppressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leflunomide: Leflunomide inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines, thereby suppressing the proliferation of activated lymphocytes. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option C. Sulphasalazine: Sulphasalazine is a prodrug that is metabolized into sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA). Its anti-inflammatory effects are primarily due to the action of 5-ASA. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine is thought to exert its anti-inflammatory effects by interfering with lysosomal activity and autophagy in immune cells, and by modulating the activity of toll-like receptors (TLRs). It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate increases extracellular adenosine by inhibiting AICAR transformylase, leading to the accumulation of AICAR, which competes with AMP deaminase and causes AMP to accumulate and be converted to adenosine outside the cell, thus exerting anti-inflammatory effects.

choices.text: Immediate surgical removal of the cyst
Start combined oral contraceptives to shrink the cyst
Follow-up with a repeat ultrasound in 6-12 weeks
Measurement of CA-125 levels

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of two uncomplicated vaginal deliveries presents to her gynecologist with complaints of dull, aching lower abdominal pain and irregular menstrual cycles for the past few months. She denies any significant weight changes, bowel or urinary symptoms, or family history of ovarian or breast cancer. On pelvic examination, a non-tender mass is palpated in the posterior fornix. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a 5 x 5 cm unilocular, clear ovarian cyst without solid components or septations. The patient is otherwise healthy and asymptomatic. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Follow-up with a repeat ultrasound in 6-12 weeks

 

Explanation:


The clear ovarian cyst described is most likely a functional ovarian cyst, which is common in reproductive-aged women. These cysts are generally benign and often resolve spontaneously. The recommended management for asymptomatic simple ovarian cysts less than 8 cm in size is to monitor the patient with a follow-up ultrasound in 6-12 weeks to confirm resolution. This conservative approach avoids unnecessary interventions in the absence of alarming symptoms or ultrasound features suggestive of malignancy.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Immediate surgical removal of the cyst: Surgery is not indicated for a simple, asymptomatic ovarian cyst of this size in a reproductive-aged woman. Surgical intervention is reserved for larger cysts, those with concerning features, or if the cyst persists over time or causes significant symptoms.

 

Option B. Start combined oral contraceptives to shrink the cyst: Although often used, oral contraceptive pills have not been proven to hasten the resolution of simple ovarian cysts. Their primary role is to prevent the formation of new cysts rather than resolving existing ones.

 

Option D. Measurement of CA-125 levels: CA-125 is a tumor marker used in the evaluation of ovarian masses, but it is not routinely indicated in young women with simple ovarian cysts due to low specificity and the potential for false-positive results from other benign conditions.

 

Educational Objective:


The best management for a simple, clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm in reproductive-aged women is conservative follow-up with repeat ultrasound in 6-12 weeks. Surgery or further investigations are not warranted unless the cyst is large, symptomatic, or has suspicious features.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the image given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dermoid

 

Ocular dermoids are choristomas, containing tissue not normally found in the area. They often appear as round, firm, and sometimes hair-bearing lesions on the surface of the eye or near the eyelids as given in the image. Dermoids can vary in size and may cause astigmatism if they press against the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pterygium: This is a benign growth of conjunctival tissue that extends onto the cornea. It often presents as a wedge-shaped, fleshy growth and is usually found on the side closest to the nose. Pterygium is often associated with exposure to sunlight or wind, and its symptoms can include redness, irritation, or a feeling of something in the eye.

 

Option B. Pinguecula: Similar to a pterygium, a pinguecula is a benign, yellowish growth that occurs on the conjunctiva. It typically appears on the side of the eye nearest to the nose but does not grow onto the cornea. Pingueculae are also associated with long-term sun exposure and can cause irritation or dryness.

 

Option D. Dermolipoma: This is a type of choristoma, like dermoids, but it primarily consists of fatty tissue. Dermolipomas are usually located on the outer corner of the eye and appear as soft, yellowish masses. They are generally benign and asymptomatic, but their size and location can occasionally cause cosmetic or functional concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and differentiating between various ocular surface lesions is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management. This involves understanding their typical presentations, etiologies, and potential complications. Regular eye examinations and proper eye protection, especially from UV light, are important for eye health.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most seen with which STI? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhoea

 

Explanation:

 

  • Gonorrhoea, caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, is known for developing significant resistance to multiple antibiotics.
  • Over the years, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has shown resistance to several classes of antibiotics, including penicillin, tetracycline, and fluoroquinolones.
  • More recently, there has been an increasing number of reports of resistance to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone, which is currently the first-line treatment for Gonorrhoea.
  • The development of drug resistance in Gonorrhoea is largely due to the bacterium's ability to acquire resistance genes through horizontal gene transfer and spontaneous mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown the same level of widespread antibiotic resistance as gonorrhoea. It is typically treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is relatively rare and has not shown significant issues with antibiotic resistance. It is usually treated with azithromycin, doxycycline, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically treated with penicillin. Although there have been some cases of resistance to macrolides like azithromycin, penicillin remains highly effective, and there is no widespread resistance to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gonorrhoea is the STI most commonly associated with significant and increasing antibiotic resistance, posing a major challenge to treatment and control efforts worldwide.

choices.text: Repeat Colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came for routine PAP smear testing. The report came as HSIL. On colposcopy and biopsy, it was confirmed to be carcinoma in situ. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conization

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix is classified as Stage 0 cancer. In a young woman with stage 0 cervical cancer, the management of choice is conization. Conization involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix, including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix. This procedure serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes:

 

  • Diagnostic: Conization provides a tissue specimen for histopathological examination, which is more definitive compared to a cytological specimen obtained from a Pap smear.
  • Therapeutic: If the histopathology shows clear margins, conization can be curative for carcinoma in situ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical treatment and is generally reserved for cases where there is invasive cancer or other indications. It is not the first-line treatment for CIS in a young woman.

 

Option C. Repeat colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months: In the case of confirmed carcinoma in situ, conization is preferred. There is no need of repeat colpobiopsy 

 

Option D. HPV DNA testing: This test is used for screening and risk assessment but is not a treatment for confirmed carcinoma in situ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conization, which involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix, is the management of choice for carcinoma in situ in young women. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic if histopathology shows clear margins.

 

 

Ref: Page no 992, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Good response to steroids

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is a type of glomerulonephritis that typically affects children and is characterized by the presence of nephrotic syndrome. The following statement is true about this condition:

 

  • Good response to steroids: MCD is often considered to be the most steroid-responsive form of nephrotic syndrome. The vast majority of children with MCD respond well to treatment with corticosteroids, with complete remission of proteinuria and edema occurring in over 90% of cases. However, the response to steroids may be less predictable in adults with MCD.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes: Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes (not light microscopy)

 

Option C. Most common in adults: it is common in pediatric age group, not adults

 

Option D. Non-selective proteinuria: the patient will have massive nephrotic range proteinuria.

 

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

 

 

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and has a very good response to corticosteroid treatment, resulting in complete remission of proteinuria and edema in over 90% of cases.

choices.text: Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours
It is dependent on psychological factors
Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period
GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of these statements regarding primary dysmenorrhea is true? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It Is dependent on psychological factors

 

Primary dysmenorrhea can be dependent on psychological factors.

 

Secondary dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours and Option C. Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period: Pain begins before or with onset of menstrual periods.

 

Option D. GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment: NSAIDs are the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by menstrual pain without underlying pelvic pathology, can be influenced by psychological factors. This type of dysmenorrhea begins before or with the onset of menstrual periods and is typically treated first with NSAIDs, not GnRH antagonists.

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital glaucoma

 

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea, along with the image suggests a diagnosis of congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.

 

 

  • Diagnostic features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.
  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy
  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
      • Goniotomy: to remove obstructed tissue in the eye's drainage system.
      • Trabeculotomy: creates a drainage opening in the eye's trabecular meshwork.
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.
      • Trabeculectomy: creates a new drainage channel for aqueous humor.
      • Tube shunt implantation: involves placing a small tube in the eye to drain excess fluid.
      • Ciliary body ablative procedures: destroy the ciliary body to reduce the production of aqueous humor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinoblastoma: A cancer that would show more than simple enlargement of the corneas, typically presenting with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria).

 

Option C. Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy: Primarily affects the endothelium of the cornea, not associated with the enlargement of the corneas or elevated IOP.

 

Option D. Megalocornea: A non-glaucomatous condition where the corneas are enlarged but without other symptoms like photophobia or increased IOP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital glaucoma is characterized by symptoms like enlarged corneas, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation due to elevated intraocular pressure from developmental anomalies in the anterior chamber angle. Early diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent permanent vision loss.

choices.text: Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding scrub typhus except: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

 

Causative organism – Orientia tsutsugamushi (an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium).

 

They cannot grow on cell free media. They are readily cultivated in yolk sac of developing chick embryos. They also grow on mouse fibroblast, HeLa, Hep-2, Detroit 6 and other continuous cell lines.

 

Vector - Infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus. Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Signs and Symptoms- Fever and chills, Headache, Body aches and muscle pain. Dark, scab-like region at the site of the chigger bite (also known as eschar). Mental changes, ranging from confusion to coma. Enlarged lymph nodes and rash are also seen.

 

Diagnosis of scrub typhus that includes enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), immunofluorescence assay (IFA), immunochromatographic test (ICT), Weil–Felix, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmitted by chiggers: This is true. Scrub typhus is transmitted by the larvae (chiggers) of trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Lymphadenopathy is a feature: This is true. Enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) are a common feature of scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Man is an accidental host: This is true. Humans are accidental hosts who become infected when they come into contact with infected chiggers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that cannot grow on cell-free media like MacConkey agar. It requires living cells for its cultivation. Scrub typhus is transmitted by chiggers and features symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite. Humans are accidental hosts for this infection.

choices.text: Women aged 25 to 65 years
Women aged 21 to 45 years
Women aged 30 to 60 years
Women aged 40 to 75 years

questions.text: A woman visits her gynecologist for a routine check-up. She has been generally healthy, is sexually active, and has no significant medical history. She has never been diagnosed with any form of cancer and has no family history of cervical or other gynecological cancers. During the consultation, she asks about the necessity of cervical cancer screening, as she has not undergone any tests in the past five years. The physician emphasizes on the importance of regular screening for cervical cancer to prevent serious outcomes. Based on the latest guidelines, which group of individuals should be screened for cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Women aged 25 to 65 years

 

Explanation:


According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines (2020), cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years. Screening should begin at age 25, with the preferred method being HPV testing every 5 years. Alternatively, HPV/Pap co-testing every 5 years or a Pap test alone every 3 years is acceptable. After the age of 65, screening can be stopped if there have been previous normal test results. The World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines (2020) recommend starting screening at age 30, primarily using HPV testing every 5 to 10 years. These guidelines are designed to detect pre-cancerous changes early and reduce the risk of developing cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:


Cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years, with HPV testing every 5 years as the preferred method. Screening helps detect pre-cancerous changes and significantly reduces the risk of cervical cancer, emphasizing the importance of adhering to current guidelines for early detection and management.

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Among the OCD subtypes, hoarding has shown to be more resistant to treatment with ERP. This might be because individuals with hoarding disorder often do not recognize their behavior as problematic and may lack insight into the disorder.

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy that is effective for many individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, certain subtypes or themes of OCD might respond less effectively to ERP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: While challenging, ERP can be tailored to address pathological doubt by creating exposures that trigger doubt without seeking reassurance.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: ERP can also be adapted for magical thinking by exposing the individual to the feared situation or thought without engaging in the ritualistic behavior.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: Contamination fears are typically one of the subtypes that respond quite well to ERP, as the therapist can create direct exposures involving the feared contaminant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hoarding disorder is characterised by acquiring and not being able to discard things that are considered to have little or no use. This will lead to cluttering of house, to an extent that it becomes unsafe to live. This disorder is driven by fear of losing something important. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.  Hoarding disorder tends to have a poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 431.

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer
Median age of survival is 6 months in all cases

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. She was diagnosed with cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. The post-operative biopsy reports came back positive for gallbladder carcinoma. What is true about gallbladder carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer

 

This statement is correct. The clinical presentation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) and gallbladder cancer (carcinoma) can sometimes be distinguished. Gallstones commonly cause symptoms such as biliary colic (episodic, severe right upper quadrant pain) and may lead to acute cholecystitis, which includes symptoms like pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In contrast, gallbladder carcinoma may present with more persistent or progressive symptoms, including unexplained weight loss and, in some cases, a palpable abdominal mass. The two conditions can have overlapping symptoms, but their clinical courses can be distinguished based on the duration and progression of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign: This statement is not true. A palpable abdominal lump is not typically the earliest sign of gallbladder carcinoma. Gallbladder carcinoma often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. As the cancer progresses, it may cause other symptoms, but a palpable lump is usually a late finding.

 

Option B. Earliest sign is jaundice: This statement is also not true for most cases of gallbladder carcinoma. Jaundice is more commonly associated with cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma) or pancreatic cancer when the tumor obstructs the bile ducts. While gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice if it obstructs the common bile duct, it is not typically the earliest sign of the disease.

 

Option D. Median age of survival is 6 months: This statement is not accurate for all cases of gallbladder carcinoma. The survival rate for gallbladder carcinoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the stage at diagnosis and the extent of surgical resection. While some cases have a poor prognosis with a short median survival, others may have a better outcome if diagnosed at an earlier stage and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Option C is correct because gallstones and gallbladder carcinoma often have distinct clinical presentations, allowing them to be distinguished from each other.

choices.text: Mean = median, not equal to mode
Mode = median, not equal to mean

questions.text: The image shows two data distribution curves from separate studies within the same population: one depicted with a red line and the other with a blue line. Given the graphical representation, which of the following correctly represents the relationship among the mean, median, and mode for the data presented? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mean = median, not equal to mode

 

Analyzing the two graphs, we observe different distribution patterns:

 

  • Red line (Study A): The distribution is unimodal and symmetrical, indicating that the mean, median, and mode are all equal.
  • Blue line (Study B): The distribution is bimodal, showing two distinct peaks. In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median are typically equal, but there are two modes, making the mode not equal to the mean or median.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median can be equal, but the mode will not be equal to them, as there are two modes.

questions.text: A patient is brought with altered sensorium and seizures. Attendant shows the laboratory report which reveals elevated transaminases. Which of the following can be used in this condition? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oxazepam
 

Oxazepam is a short acting Benzodiazepine, which has no active metabolites and can be used safely in a patient with active liver disease. Other BZDs that can be used include Temazepam, Lorazepam, Estazolam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midazolam: Midazolam is metabolized in the liver through oxidative pathways and produces active metabolites. It is not the best choice for patients with liver impairment.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is metabolized in the liver to active metabolites, which can accumulate in patients with liver dysfunction, potentially leading to prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option C. Alprazolam: Alprazolam is also metabolized in the liver through oxidative processes and has active metabolites. It is not recommended for patients with significant liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with elevated transaminases, it is crucial to use medications that are not heavily reliant on hepatic metabolism and do not produce active metabolites. Oxazepam, being metabolized via conjugation, is a safer option in such scenarios compared to other benzodiazepines like midazolam, diazepam, and alprazolam.

 

Remember with mnemonic ‘STOLE’

 

Short-acting Benzodiazepines

 

  • Temazepam
  • Oxazepam
  • Lorazepam
  • Estazolam

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetaminophen

 

In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like naproxen, indomethacin, and diclofenac are generally avoided due to their potential to worsen renal function. These medications inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, which can lead to renal vasoconstriction and further decline in kidney function.

 

Acetaminophen (paracetamol), on the other hand, is generally considered safer for patients with CKD when used at appropriate doses. It has a different mechanism of action (inhibit COX3) and does not significantly affect renal hemodynamics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naproxen: Naproxen is an NSAID that can significantly impair renal function, especially in patients with pre-existing kidney disease. It should be avoided in this population due to the risk of worsening kidney function and potential for causing renal failure.

 

Option B. Indomethacin: Indomethacin is another NSAID with similar risks to naproxen. Its use can lead to decreased renal perfusion and exacerbate renal impairment, making it unsuitable for patients with CKD.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac, like other NSAIDs, poses a significant risk to kidney function in patients with CKD. It can reduce prostaglandin synthesis, leading to renal vasoconstriction and further renal impairment, and should be avoided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetaminophen is the preferred postoperative analgesic for patients with chronic kidney disease, as it does not significantly affect renal function and is safer than NSAIDs in this population.

questions.text: Identify the given condition: (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Given histology image shows a suprabasal blister which points to a diagnosis of Pemphigus Vulgaris.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leprosy: Tuberculoid leprosy (paucibacillary) will show granulomatous lesions while lepromatous lesions (multibacillary) shows lipid-laden macrophages (lepra cells) filled with masses (globi) of acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides: Lower portion of the epidermis contains hyperchromatic enlarged lymphocytes. Pautrier’s microabscesses may be seen which are intradermal clusters of atypical lymphoid cells.

 

 

Option D. Visceral Leishmaniasis: Visceral Leishmaniasis shows skin lesion with abundant amastigotes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by suprabasal blisters and a row of tombstone appearance on histology, with a fishnet pattern on direct immunofluorescence due to IgG deposition.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 2307-2308

questions.text: A drug trial was initiated under Medicine department to test the efficacy of a new medication in comparison to a placebo. The participants were divided into two cohorts. Cohort A received a placebo, while cohort B was treated with the novel drug. Out of the 120 participants in cohort A, 36 faced fatal outcomes. In cohort B, with 130 participants, there were 26 fatal outcomes. Given this data, if a clinician were to incorporate this novel medication into practice, how many patients would they need to treat with this new medication to prevent one additional fatality when compared to the placebo group? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 10

 

10 patients need to be treated with the new drug to avert 1 death.

 

We can group divide the case scenario into two groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26 Treatment failures out of 130

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36 Treatment failures out of 120

 

 

Now, we have to calculate failure rate in both groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26/130 = 0.2

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36/120 = 0.3

 

 Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference of failure in both groups = 0.3 – 0.2 = 0.1

 

Number needed to treat (NNT) = 1/ARR = 1/0.1 = 10

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Number Needed to Treat (NNT) is a practical measure used in decision-making for clinical interventions.
  • It represents the number of patients that need to be treated with a particular therapy over a specific period to prevent one additional bad outcome, such as death in this scenario.
  • An NNT of 10 indicates that the new medication has a significant impact in reducing fatalities compared to the placebo.

questions.text: What should be the ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4%

 

Explanation:

 

  • Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.
  • As per the strict criteria, >4% normal forms of morphology must be present.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis is >4% according to WHO 2010 criteria.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg442, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

choices.text: A-1 B-2 C-3
A-2 B-1 C-3
A-3 B-2 C-1
A-1 B-3 C-2

questions.text: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2 B-1 C-3

 

Dilutions of adrenaline (epinephrine) with their typical uses:

 

  1. 1:1000 dilution of adrenaline is more concentrated and is commonly used in the treatment of Anaphylaxis. It is administered intramuscularly in emergency situations for its rapid vasoconstrictive and bronchodilating effects.
  2. 1:10000 dilution is less concentrated and is typically used in the management of Cardiac Arrest. It's administered intravenously.
  3. 1:100000 dilution is used as an additive in Local Anesthesia. The vasoconstrictive properties of adrenaline help to prolong the action of the local anesthetic and reduce bleeding in the surgical field.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

 

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

 

This is a rare type of breast cancer that occurs more frequently in older women and grows slowly. The prognosis of colloid carcinoma is better than that of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

 

The tumor is typically a soft, gelatinous mass with well-defined borders.

 

Histologically, colloid carcinoma has a lot of extracellular epithelial mucin and mucin-filled acini. Floating in large lakes of mucin are cuboidal to tall columnar tumor cells, some of which show mucus vacuolation. Nuclei in intracellular type are pushed to the periphery, forming a signet ring appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary carcinoma of the breast is characterized by the presence of papillary structures lined by neoplastic cells.

 

  • It does not typically present with large pools of mucin.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is characterized by large, high-grade cells with a syncytial growth pattern, prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders.

 

  • It lacks the extensive mucin pools seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single-file lines or targetoid patterns.

 

  • It typically lacks the mucin pools characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

choices.text: 95% Ethyl Alcohol
Acetic Acid Solution

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to your office for her annual gynecological examination. She has no significant medical history, is a non-smoker, and has been compliant with her routine screenings. During the exam, a Pap smear is performed to screen for cervical cancer, and the clinician emphasizes the importance of immediate fixation of the sample to preserve cellular morphology for accurate evaluation. What is the most appropriate fixative used for preserving the Pap smear sample in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 95% Ethyl Alcohol

 

Explanation:


The standard fixative for Pap smears is 95% ethyl alcohol, which effectively preserves the cellular details necessary for cytological evaluation by preventing autolysis and degradation of the cells. This fixative ensures that the morphology of the cells is maintained, which is critical for identifying any cellular abnormalities such as dysplasia or carcinoma. Proper fixation allows for an accurate interpretation of the smear, which is essential in cervical cancer screening. Modern practice also employs ethanol sprays, which offer a convenient alternative for immediate fixation in clinical settings.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Formalin: Formalin is commonly used in histopathology to fix tissue samples but is unsuitable for Pap smears as it can cause cellular shrinkage and artifacts that hinder cytological evaluation.

 

Option C. Acetic Acid Solution: Acetic acid is primarily used to enhance the visibility of cellular abnormalities during colposcopy but does not preserve cellular structure and morphology, making it inappropriate as a Pap smear fixative.

 

Option D. Methanol: Methanol can serve as a fixative, but it is less commonly used compared to 95% ethyl alcohol due to its lower effectiveness in preserving the fine details of cellular morphology necessary for accurate Pap smear evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:


95% Ethyl alcohol is the most commonly used fixative for Pap smears, crucial for preserving cellular morphology and preventing degradation, allowing for accurate cytological assessment and early detection of cervical abnormalities

questions.text: Inhalational anaesthetic agent of choice in children is(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

  • Sevoflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent of choice in children.
