It has a rapid onset and offset, a pleasant smell, and causes minimal airway irritation, making it ideal for inhalational induction in pediatric patients. It also has a relatively low blood-gas partition coefficient, leading to quick recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is another potent inhalational anesthetic with a very low blood-gas partition coefficient, resulting in rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia. However, it can cause airway irritation and coughing, making it less suitable for children, particularly for inhalational induction.

 

Option C. Nitrous oxide: Nitrous oxide is commonly used as an adjunct to other anesthetic agents due to its analgesic properties and rapid onset. However, it is not used as the sole agent for induction of anesthesia because it is not potent enough to achieve surgical anesthesia on its own.

 

Option D. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is a potent inhalational anesthetic but has a pungent odor and can cause airway irritation. It is less commonly used for inhalational induction in children due to these properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, sevoflurane is preferred for pediatric anesthesia due to its favorable profile, including rapid onset and recovery, minimal airway irritation, and a pleasant smell, making it well-tolerated by children.

questions.text: A person comes to the OPD with symptoms of not using his left side and not washing the left side of his body while bathing. On examination he wasn't able to draw the left side of the images. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right posterior parietal area

 

The symptoms described indicate left-sided hemi-neglect, which is typically due to a lesion in the non-dominant (right) posterior parietal area, responsible for spatial awareness and attention.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Left motor cortex: Would result in right-sided motor deficits.


Option B. Right motor cortex: Would result in left-sided motor deficits but not neglect.


Option C. Left posterior parietal area: Would result in right-sided hemi-neglect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left-sided neglect is often due to a lesion in the right posterior parietal area.

questions.text: Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. So, on SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is likely to occur? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process used for plasma can safely inactivate all lipid-enveloped virus. HAV is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it's not affected by solvent/detergent (SD) plasma.

 

Hepatitis B, C, and HIV are enveloped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV): HIV is an enveloped virus. The SD process effectively inactivates HIV by disrupting its lipid envelope, making it non-infectious.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBV is also an enveloped virus. The SD process disrupts the lipid envelope of HBV, rendering it non-infectious.

 

Option D. Hepatitis C Virus (HCV): HCV is another enveloped virus. The SD process targets and inactivates HCV by disrupting its lipid envelope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process inactivates lipid-enveloped viruses such as HIV, HBV, and HCV. However, it does not inactivate non-enveloped viruses like Hepatitis A Virus (HAV), making HAV infections a potential risk during SD plasma transfusion.

questions.text: Which one is not helpful in DNA Double stand break repair? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MSH 2

 

MSH 2 is part of the mismatch repair (MMR) system and does not play a direct role in repairing double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA. Its main function is to correct base-pair mismatches and insertion-deletion loops during DNA replication and recombination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATM: Ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM) protein is crucial for recognizing DNA double-strand breaks and initiating repair via the homologous recombination pathway.

 

Option B. BRCA 1: Breast cancer type 1 susceptibility protein is involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks predominantly through the homologous recombination pathway.

 

Option D. Ku 70: Ku 70, along with Ku 80, forms the Ku heterodimer, which binds to DNA double-strand breaks and plays a critical role in the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) repair pathway.

 

Educational objective:

 

MSH 2 is associated with mismatch repair and not directly involved in the repair mechanisms of double-strand breaks, which are crucial processes for maintaining genomic stability and preventing malignant transformations

choices.text: It is a screening test for cervical cancer
It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital tract
It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with repeated infections of trichomonas vaginitis; her physician advises for a Pap smear. She asks you regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your appropriate response? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a screening test for cervical cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer.
  • A cervical smear is prepared using the pap test which is sent for cytological examination
  • The presence of malignant cells on Pap smear requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage, etc.

 

Prerequisites:

 

  • It should be done prior to vaginal examination
  • Lubricants should not be used
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test
  • The ideal time is around ovulation
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas vaginalis: Trichomonas vaginalis is diagnosed by seeing the flagellated organism (T. vaginalis) on a vaginal smear

 

Option C. It helps to diagnose cervical cancer in her genital tract: A pap smear is specifically for cervical cancer screening and also for recurrence from the vaginal vault following hysterectomy for CIN/ cervical cancer.

 

Option D. It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her: A pap smear can detect associated genital infections especially cervical infections but is not routinely used for this purpose

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer, used to identify abnormal cells in the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 113, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.

 

Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.

 

Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.

 

Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:

  • Origin: Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • Branchial Fistula: The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the limbic system?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Amygdala

2. Hippocampus

3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The limbic system is a complex set of brain structures located on both sides of the thalamus, immediately beneath the cerebrum. It includes key components such as the amygdala, hippocampus, thalamus, hypothalamus, basal ganglia, and cingulate gyrus. These structures support a variety of functions related to emotions, behavior, motivation, long-term memory, and olfaction.

 

  1. Amygdala: Integral for processing emotions, the amygdala is especially involved in fear, anxiety, and social cognition. It also plays a significant role in forming and retrieving emotional memories.
  2. Hippocampus: Essential for learning and memory, the hippocampus is pivotal in the consolidation of information from short-term memory to long-term memory and spatial navigation.
  3. Thalamus: Although primarily known as the relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, the thalamus also supports functions of the limbic system by regulating consciousness, sleep, and alertness.

 

Other structures are :

 

The hypothalamus is involved in regulating many bodily functions, including hunger, thirst, body temperature, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a key role in the regulation of the autonomic nervous system and the endocrine system.

 

The cingulate gyrus is involved in a variety of functions, including emotion regulation, attention, and the processing of pain.

 

Together, these structures form a complex network that plays a crucial role in many aspects of human behavior and cognition. Dysfunction or damage to the limbic system can lead to a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The limbic system’s role is critical, as its structures are deeply integrated into the processes governing emotions, memory, and essential physiological functions. Damage or dysfunction in any part of the limbic system can lead to profound psychological and cognitive impairments, affecting everything from emotional regulation to memory processing.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and difficulty conceiving. She reports that her periods have been irregular since her teenage years, and she has gained weight in the past two years. Physical examination reveals central obesity and signs of androgen excess, such as increased facial hair and acne. An ultrasound confirms the presence of multiple ovarian follicles consistent with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The patient is interested in starting treatment to help regulate her cycles and improve her chances of conception. Which of the following is not typically used in the management of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:


Tamoxifen is not typically used in the management of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator primarily used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer rather than managing symptoms of PCOS. It does not address key aspects of PCOS management such as ovulation induction, insulin resistance, or androgen suppression, which are essential in treating this condition.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Anti-androgens: Anti-androgens, such as spironolactone and finasteride, are used in PCOS to manage symptoms of androgen excess, including hirsutism and acne. These medications help reduce hair growth and improve skin appearance but are not used when trying to conceive due to their anti-androgenic effects.

 

Option B. Gonadotropins: Gonadotropins, such as FSH and LH, are used in PCOS for ovulation induction, particularly when other treatments like clomiphene or letrozole have failed. They are administered under careful monitoring to stimulate the ovaries directly, aiding in fertility management for women with PCOS.

 

Option C. Letrozole: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor widely used as a first-line treatment for ovulation induction in women with PCOS. It works by lowering estrogen levels, leading to an increase in FSH release, which stimulates ovulation, making it particularly useful for women trying to conceive.

 

Educational Objective:


PCOS management includes addressing hormonal imbalances, insulin resistance, and hyperandrogenism symptoms. Treatment options include anti-androgens for androgen excess, gonadotropins for ovarian stimulation in fertility treatment, and letrozole for ovulation induction. Tamoxifen is not used in PCOS management, as it does not target these essential aspects of the condition.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Ehrlichia chaffeensis

questions.text: Image of Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ehrlichia chaffeensis

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is an obligate intracellular, Gram-negative species of Rickettsiales bacteria. It is a zoonotic pathogen transmitted to humans by the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum) and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME).

 

Ehrlichiosis is evidenced by the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions known as morulae in monocytes, which can be observed on a Giemsa-stained blood film.

 

Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Transmission: By the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum).
  • Symptoms: Patients typically exhibit symptoms within 1 to 2 weeks after tick infection. Early symptoms include fever, headache, malaise, low-back pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Some patients may also have myalgias, arthralgias, coughing, pharyngitis, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and changes in mental status.
  • Diagnosis: Besides observing morulae in monocytes, serological tests like indirect fluorescent antibody tests and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are also used for diagnosis.
  • Treatment: TOC Doxycycline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect. Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), typically associated with rash and vascular endothelial damage, not morulae in monocytes.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect. Rickettsia conorii causes Mediterranean spotted fever, which also does not present with morulae in monocytes.

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Incorrect. Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA), where morulae are found in granulocytes, not monocytes. The presence of morulae in granulocytes is characteristic of Anaplasma infection.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is identified by the presence of morulae in monocytes and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis. The proper treatment is doxycycline, and diagnosis is confirmed through blood smear, serological tests, and PCR.

 

GAME – Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis

questions.text: Sideroblastic anemia can be treated by?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Pyridoxine

 

Option A. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine, also known as vitamin B6, can be effective in treating certain forms of sideroblastic anemia, particularly those associated with a deficiency in pyridoxine-dependent enzymes. It helps improve heme synthesis and reduce the accumulation of iron in the mitochondria of red blood cell precursors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not typically used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia. Thiamine deficiency can lead to other conditions, such as beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but it is not directly related to sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. B3: Vitamin B3, also known as niacin, is not typically used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia. Niacin deficiency can lead to pellagra but is not directly associated with this type of anemia.

 

Option D. B12: Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for the production of red blood cells and is used in the treatment of megaloblastic anemias, such as those caused by vitamin B12 deficiency or folate deficiency. It is not a primary treatment for sideroblastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sideroblastic anemia can be treated with Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation, which helps improve heme synthesis and reduce iron accumulation in red blood cell precursors.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 310

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 -1 - 3 - 4- 5

 

The auditory pathway begins at the peripheral sensory receptors and progresses through a series of nuclei and tracts in the central nervous system before reaching the auditory cortex. The correct sequence from the periphery to the higher centers is:

 

  • Spiral ganglion (2): Located in Rosenthal's canal within the cochlea, the spiral ganglion contains bipolar neurons that send fibers through the cochlear nerve (part of the eighth cranial nerve) to the brainstem.
  • Cochlear nucleus (1): The first central auditory nucleus where the cochlear nerve fibers terminate.
  • Superior olivary nucleus (3): Serves as a major binaural processing center in the brainstem, crucial for localizing sounds in space.
  • Inferior colliculus (4): Acts as an important relay station in the midbrain, integrating auditory input before sending it to the thalamus.
  • Medial geniculate body (5): Part of the thalamus, this structure further processes auditory information before transmitting it to the auditory cortex.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve

  2. Cochlear Nucleus

  3. Superior Olivary nucleus

  4. Lateral lemniscus

  5. Inferior colliculus

  6. Medial geniculate body

  7. Auditory cortex

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 15

questions.text: Identify the rules used as tests of insanity? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both A and B

 

  • Durham's rule and Curren's rule are used in cases as tests for insanity.

  • The Durham's rule states, “an accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act was the product of mental disease or mental defect”.

  • The Curren's rule states that “an accused person will not be criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of law, as a result of mental disease or defect”.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Durham's rule and Curren's rule are significant tests used to determine criminal responsibility in cases where the defendant's mental state is in question.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the neck undergoes radical neck dissection. Which of the following structures is typically spared during this procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digastric muscle

 

Radical neck dissection spares the digastric muscle.

 

  • The digastric muscle is typically spared during a radical neck dissection. This muscle is important for several functions, including swallowing and jaw movement.
  • Preservation of the digastric muscle helps maintain normal swallowing and chewing abilities, which is essential for a patient's quality of life postoperatively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A radical neck dissection is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of lymph nodes level 1 to 5, ipsilateral submandibular gland and tail of parotid, as well as other structures in the neck such as the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve.

 

In modified radical neck dissections, some structures may be spared, such as the internal jugular vein, sternocleidomastoid muscle or the spinal accessory nerve.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency

 

The clinical scenario describes a 3-year-old girl with ambiguous genitalia, specifically an enlarged clitoris, and a karyotype of 46XX. This presentation is indicative of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), which is most commonly caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of CAH and accounts for more than 95% of cases. This enzyme deficiency leads to impaired cortisol production, which results in an increased production of androgens. The excess androgens cause virilization, leading to ambiguous genitalia in genotypically female infants.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ambiguous genitalia: This includes an enlarged clitoris, which is often a sign of virilization due to increased androgens.
  • Karyotype 46XX: Confirms the genetic female status.
  • Increased serum androgens: Result from the enzyme deficiency and lead to masculinization of the external genitalia.

 

Clinical scenario: Ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 11 hydroxylase deficiency: This can also lead to CAH but is less common and typically presents with hypertension due to the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone, which has mineralocorticoid activity.

 

Option C. 3 beta dehydrogenase deficiency: This is a rarer form of CAH and typically presents with both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiencies along with ambiguous genitalia in both sexes.

 

Option D. 2, 3 lyase deficiency: This is not a commonly recognized cause of CAH. The primary enzyme deficiencies leading to CAH are 21-hydroxylase, 11-hydroxylase, and 17-hydroxylase deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female (46XX) is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
